solution: Since line $RQ$ is perpendicular to line $k$, and $l\parallel k$, line $RQ$ is perpendicular to $l$ as well.  Therefore, $\angle RQS = 90^\circ$.  We also have $\angle RSQ = 180^\circ - 130^\circ = 50^\circ$.  The angles of $\triangle RSQ$ add to $180^\circ$, so $\angle SRQ = 180^\circ - \angle RSQ - \angle RQS = 180^\circ - 50^\circ - 90^\circ = \boxed{40^\circ}$.
